Description: Solid-cast bird foot and lower leg in copper alloy; all four claws complete with backwards facing one smaller; fine incised details on the leg and claws; fitting element of a bird figure, most likely a falcon, often associated with Horus; tang at either end for attachment; complete fitting; slightly corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar fittings for falcon figures were discovered in Naukratis: BM 1885,1101.108; Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H1082.2; Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,114; possibly Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H2205.10 and BM 2011,5009.22 (only small fragments). Falcon bronzes are usually associated with Horus (Weiss 2012, 281-282), though several deities and the pharaoh himself are linked with this form (Davies, Smith 2005, 54). This element could belong to either types T18 or T19 depending if the falcon was crowned or not (Weiss 2012, 738-745, Pl. 43c-f and 44, Typ T18-19, see Nr. 1394 for this specimen). Such bronze figures are well documented in the Memphite region, particularly in the falcon complex and catacomb in North Saqqara (Davies, Smith 2005). A few more specimens were found in Herakleion and Athribis. Numerous falcon figures, mainly amuletic figures made out of copper alloy, but also glazed composition, stone and Egyptian blue, were discovered in Naukratis, including rather large amuletic figures in glazed composition likely produced locally (Masson forthcoming). Davies, S., Smith, H.S. 2005, The sacred animal necropolis at North Saqqara: the falcon complex and catacomb (Egypt Exploration Society Memoirs 73), London. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at the British Museum, 22nd – 23rd June 2013.
